note: . . style: i.e. rhetoric. See De Finibus 2. 17, where dialectic is contrasted with rhetoric. Cicero now goes on to embrace the three types of rhetoric: deliberative, judicial, and demonstrative (i.e. the rhetoric of display).
title: a kind of stockade: according to D.L. 7. 40, this was a Stoic image. a more expansive
my version of Aratus' poem: for fragments of Cicero's version see Traglia
those gentlemen: philosophers using Socrates' method of interrogation
a measure of consent: see Plato

the procession of the stars etc.: this recalls the eloquent passage in De Natura Deorum 2. 87–119, which contains a translation of Aristotle's De Philosophia (95); see Pease's notes. it has to be admitted etc.: the reasoning is fallacious. This becomes clear when 'superior' (praestare) is taken to mean 'superior in intelligence' and one attempts to set out the propositions in the form of a syllogism
the preamble to the legal code: see Plato

title: . said: according to D.L
Thales said that the world was animate and full of divinities

title: First­born Fortune: the first­born daughter of Jupiter (Fortuna Primigenia) had a temple on the Capitol (P­A 217–18

note: I agree with Plato: see Plato, Republic 4. 424d. the laws of music: for the social implications of music see Plato, Laws 3. 700–1, Aristotle, Pol. 8. 5–7 (Barker), and Horace, Ars Poetica 202–19, with Brink's notes.
title: Bacchanalia: the disorderly rites in honour of Bacchus got out of hand in 186 and were suppressed by the Senate. For details see Livy 39. 8–18 and Walsh's article. In his work: Cicero is thought to refer to a scene in the lost Horai (Seasons), of which one fragment reads 'Sabazius, the Phrygian, the flute­player'

Cf. Birds 873–5 and Wasps 9. Sabazius was a Phrygian deity whose cult was widespread in Asia Minor. His worship was especially popular with women and slaves. ''The other gods' may well have included Adonis; see Lysistrata 387–90 and Strabo

note: 213 Cleisthenes: this story is also uncorroborated. There is no record elsewhere of Cleisthenes having daughters. Plato: a reference to Plato, Laws 4. 716–17.
title: Pythian Apollo: in Xenophon
16 the oracle says 'Follow the custom of the state'; cf

just a few days: the Megalensian festival in honour of Cybele or the Great Mother (megale in Greek meant 'great'), was held during 4–10 April. Lucretius describes how, at the procession, onlookers threw silver and copper coins into the roadway (De Rerum Natura 2. 626–7). In his fulminations against Cybele Augustine mentions her devotees in Carthage collecting money 'even from shopkeepers' (De Civitate Dei 7. 26). See also Frazer iii. 198–202. Such collections were not for charity, but for the cult itself. Alexander: there appears to be no confirmation of this story

McQueen points out that while Alexander might have deposited the 200­talent fine paid by the people in a temple during the celebrations which he organized, he would hardly have left it behind when he departed, for he was seriously short of money

note: Minerva had long been worshipped on the Capitol along with Jupiter and Juno. See T. N. Mitchell 138.
title: a temple of Licence: a sardonic distortion. The temple erected by Clodius on the site of Cicero's demolished house on the Palatine was dedicated to Liberty. the deity who was the guardian of the city: before leaving Rome, Cicero took a statue of Minerva from his house to the temple of Jupiter on the Capitol, where he dedicated it with the inscription 'To Minerva
Plato's wishes: see Laws 12

note: Keyes). See Festus under membrum abscidi mortuo (Lindsay 135).
title: whose name is derived from death: Cicero's etymology is supported by OLD, which sees de nece (piare) as the origin of the word. the household god: i.e. the Lar. the severed bone: before cremation a piece of the body (normally a finger) was cut off and retained for burial 'in deference to the older custom'
One of the laws of the Twelve Tables
Do no more than this

note: heroic lines: i.e. hexameters.
title: . says this: see Laws 12

note: Magistrates: see Appendix. Plato: Plato, Laws 3. 701c.
title: six earlier books: the Republic, where the best constitution was said to be a mixture of monarchy, oligarchy, and democracy

note: see note on L. 1. 10 above). Cicero complains about the practice in section 1 below. Cf. De Lege Agraria (Contra Rullum) 1. 8.
title: no one shall be appointed ambassador: a reference to 'free embassies'

Had I not given way: some scholars, reading si without a negative, take the passage as referring to the revolt of Catiline. what I did for the safety of the country: Cicero represents his departure as an act undertaken in the public interest

note: He began to work for Cicero's recall and eventually persuaded Caesar to agree (T. N. Mitchell 150 ff.). Hence Cicero's mildness. a cause . . . not intrinsically disastrous: the restoration of the tribunate.
title: eminent men: e.g. Aristides and Themistocles
A lofty interpretation of their state of mind. As for Pompey: Pompey's attitude to Clodius soon changed from acquiescence, or even support, to opposition
Crassus: i.e. Lucius Licinius Crassus
the hero of Homer's Iliad
: an authority on law, contemporary with Cato the Censor
AENIANES : a people living in the upper Spercheus valley in north­central Greece
AEQUI: a mountain tribe north­east of Rome. They fought against Rome in the fifth century, but were conquered and eventually absorbed
AESCHINES : c.397­c.322. Famous Athenian orator, opponent of Demosthenes
Latinized form of Asclepius the Greek god of healing. The cult was brought to Rome in 293, and a temple was dedicated in 291
AETOLIANS : a people of north­central Greece
: he was exiled by his ungrateful countrymen after killing Spurius Maelius, a would­be tyrant
AMALTHEA : nurse of Zeus, variously described as a nymph and a she­goat

AMPHIARAUS : a prophet who foresaw that the expedition of the seven Argive chiefs against Thebes was doomed to fail, but nevertheless took part in it at the behest of his wife, Eriphyle, who had been bribed with a necklace by Polynices

note: Exiled by Julius Caesar, he was recalled in 46 through Cicero's influence. L. 2. 6.
title: TITUS : tribune in 63, Balbus was a staunch supporter of Pompey
: fourth king of Rome (641­617). He built the first bridge over the Tiber and extended Roman territory to the coast, where he founded Ostia
: consul in 129. With a senatorial commission he organized the province of Asia
AQUILO : the north wind (the Greek Boreas
: c.287­212. Famous as a mathematician and as an inventor of ingenious devices, e.g. a screw for raising water
The most famous representative of the Greek Old Comedy, which was remarkable for its outspokenness
AULUS : consul 258 and 254, dictator 249, he was a famous general in the first Punic war (264­41
: a famous augur in the time of Tarquinius Priscus; see Livy 1. 36 with Ogilvie's note
: in about 454, with his fellow consul, Spurius Tarpeius, he brought in a law regulating fines and deposits
BUSIRIS : mythical king of Egypt who slaughtered all foreigners entering thecountry
: as tribune in 445, he introduced a bill allowing intermarriage between patricians and plebeians
: a pro­Gracchan tribune in 131, he carried a law extending the secret ballot to legislative assemblies
: grandfather of the author
CHARONDAS : a lawgiver in Catana, Rhegium, and other Sicilian centres. Most of the reports about him are fictitious
CHRYSIPPUS : c.280­206, converted from the scepticism of the Academy toStoicism by Cleanthes, whom he succeeded as Head of the school in 232. A formidable logician and a voluminous writer
on the south­east coast of Asia Minor. Now part of Turkey
APPIUS : consul 143, political rival of Scipio and father­in­law of Ti. Gracchus, with whom he served on the agrarian commission

container-title: 42. CLEINIAS: a Cretan who figures in Plato's Laws
title: GAIUS : opponent of Saturninus; aedile 99, consul 92.L. 3

CLEISTHENES: at the end of the sixth century he reorganized the Athenians into ten tribes, each containing a group from the city, the coast, and the hinterland. He also reformed the council, the assembly, and the army, thus creating the democracy of the fifth century
: after 280 he wrote a history of Alexander'sexploits which was severely criticized but widely read
GAIUS : tribune in 107, he proposed voting by ballot in trials for treason
: husband of Lucretia; consul in 509
: one of the six clans which, from early times, formed an aristocracy within the patriciate itself
TIBERIUS : consul in 280, commanded armies against theEtruscans and Pyrrhus. He was the first plebeian pontifex maximus (254­253
: as praetor in 70, he passed a law by which criminal juries should consist of senators, knights, and financial officials (tribuni Page 227

: overthrew Astyages, king of Media, in 549. He then extended his empire to embrace Asia Minor, Babylonia, Assyria, Syria, and Palestine. In spite of his vast power, he had a reputation for wisdom and magnanimity. Best known to the Romans from Xenophon's biographical novel, the Cyropedia
DIAGONDAS : an obscure Theban lawgiver
326­296. A pupil of Aristotle, he wrote voluminously on history, constitutions, literature, philosophy, and geography
: c.240­152. Pupil of Chrysippus and teacher of Panaetius, he visited Rome in 155, where he did much to develop interest in Stoicism
DOLOPES : a people of Thessaly in the centre of northern Greece
DORIS: a district in central Greece to the east of Aetolia
DRACO : a legislator who, c.620, gave Athens its first written code. Such was his severity, however, that his laws were said to have been written in blood
GAIUS : consul 260. As commander of Rome's fleet, he defeated the Carthaginians off Mylae in northeast Sicily in the first Punic war
A Sicilian noble who won fame for his writings (in verse) on natural philosophy and religion

title: in south­west Asia Minor) c.390­c.340. A mathematician, geographer, and astronomer of the first importance

GAIUS: consul 282 and 278, censor 275. Another example of early Roman austerity and integrity. His campaigns in southern Italy played a major part in the defeat of Pyrrhus
GAIUS : consul 122, son­in­law of Laelius. It is uncertain whether he or another Gaius Fannius wrote a history of his own times

Heracles, the most popular of all Greek heroes. At a very early stage his cult came to Rome, where he was worshipped at the Ara Maxima (Greatest Altar) and several other places

'the father of history'. Born in Halicarnassus in Caria (Asia Minor) probably in the 490s, he lived until the 420s. He travelled extensively, gathering information of all kinds, which he used in his history of the Persian wars
king of the gods, identified with the Greek Zeus

LUCERES : one of the three tribes of early Rome, allegedly derived from a supporter of Romulus called Lucumo
LYCURGUS : according to tradition, he was the founder of the Spartan constitution
: consul 149; a prominent orator and jurist

MEGILLUS : a Spartan who figures in Plato's Laws
MELAMPUS : a legendary Greek prophet who came to understand the speech of birds and animals

MINOS: prehistoric and semi­legendary king of Crete. His name has been given to the bronze­age civilization of Crete

note: see Scaevola (2).
title: MOPSUS : famous prophet, son of Apollo and Teiresias' daughter
SPURIUS : an orator in the Stoic style; he accompanied Scipio to the east in 140­39

title: He played a major part in the capture of Troy. He also figured in drama
ORITHYIA : daughter of Erechtheus, mythical king of Athens. She was carried off by the north wind while playing by the Ilissus

title: PANAETIUS: c.185­109. Pupil of Diogenes of Babylon. Came to Rome c.144 and joined Scipio's group of friends. Head of the Stoa from 129­109. His form of Stoicism suited the practical Roman mind
PHAEDRUS : c.140­70, An Epicurean whom Cicero heard lecture in Rome before 88 and again ten years later in Athens
PHALARIS : tyrant of Agrigentum in Sicily, c.570­550. He became a byword for cruelty by roasting his victims alive inside a bronze bull
PHLIASIANS : from Phlius in the north­east Peloponnese
PHOENICIANS : in modern Lebanon and northern Israel. See Carthaginians
PISIDIANS : in southern Asia Minor
: a prolific and popular writer of Graeco­Roman comedy in the late third and early second centuries

note: POLLUX : see Castor.
title: : head of the Academy from 314­270

container-title: An important source for Livy. R
title: POLYBIUS : b. c.200, died after 118. A major Greek historian who recorded the rise of Rome in 40 books from 220­146. He ascribed Rome's supremacy to her mixed constitution, her army, and her early development. Though rather dull, he was a scholarly and honest writer
POLYIDUS : a mythical Corinthian prophet and miracle­worker
POSTUMUS COMINIUS : consul 493 with Spurius Cassius

note: claimed that the ascended Romulus had appeared to him (Livy
PUBLICOLA : see Valerius.
title: : a farmer from Alba Longa, who had come to Rome for the day
ROMULUS (the o is long): mythical founder of Rome. See under Remus, above
RUTULI : an ancient people of Latium, whose capital was Ardea, some 20 miles (32km.) south of Rome. Ardea was the home of Turnus in the Aeneid

SAMNITES: a hardy people living to the east of Latium. Rome's main Italian rival in the fourth century, they assisted Pyrrhus and Hannibal in the third, and continued to oppose the Romans down to the time of Sulla

container-title: One of the seven planets. R
title: SATURN : an old god identified by the Romans with the Greek Kronos, who was ousted by Zeus and took refuge in Latium, where he presided over a golden age
SCAEVOLA (1), PUBLIUS MUCIUS: consul 133; an eminent lawyer; opponent of Scipio; adviser of Ti
SCAEVOLA (2), QUINTUS MUCIUS 'THE AUGUR': son­in­law of Laelius; consul 117; a distinguished lawyer who taught Cicero

container-title: 100 led the Senate against Saturninus and his supporters
title: : consul 115, married a Metella and became leader of the Metellus faction. Censor 109
GNAEUS CORNELIUS: consul 222. Was sent to Spain to work with his brother (Scipio 2) against the Carthaginian Hasdrubal. They captured Saguntum in 212, but both were defeated and killed in 211
PUBLIUS CORNELIUS: consul 218; father of Scipio Africanus Major (3). Defeated by Hannibal in 218, sent to Spain in 217, where he met his death

Gracchus agitated for a second tribunate, Nasica led a crowd of senators to the assembly, where they killed Gracchus and large numbers of his followers, thus incurring the odium of the people
SERVIUS SULPICIUS GALBA : consul 144. A famous orator; but as a general he contributed to Rome's reputation for treachery in Spain
239 SERVIUS TULLIUS : sixth king of Rome (578­535). For discussion of the problems concerning his reign, see Cornell, index under Tullius
: a patrician tried for murder before the Assembly of the Centuries
A famous lyric and elegiac poet. For testimonia and fragments, see Campbell, iii

title: STATA MATER : an old goddess who was supposed to give protection against fire
TAURIANS : a people living on the mountainous south coast of the Crimea. Their maiden goddess, to whom strangers were sacrificed (Herodotus 4. 103) was identified with the Greek Artemis

A pupil of Isocrates and a prolific historian. He continued Thucydides' work from 411 to 394, concentrating on the supremacy of Sparta. He also wrote a universal history in 58 books, starting from the accession of Philip of Macedon in 359

THESEUS : legendary hero of Attica, which he is supposed to have unified into one state with Athens as its capital. For his numerous exploits, of which the most famous is his killing of the Minotaur and his elopement with Ariadne, see Plutarch, Theseus
A Pythagorean philosopher, chief speaker in Plato's Timaeaus
of Tauromenium in north­east Sicily: c.356­260. Fled to Athens, where he lived for 50 years. He wrote a history of Sicily in 38 books, which was admired by Polybius and Cicero
: c.450­360. He developed the range of the lyre by increasing the number of its strings from seven to twelve, and was criticized for doing so
TITIES: the tribe named after Titus Tatius (see above
: consul 244, 241; censor 247
Scipio's nephew; a Stoic jurist
PUBLIUS POSTUMIUS : consul 505 and 504. He campaigned successfully against the Sabines

VESTA : the hearth goddess, etymologically connected with the Greek Hestia. The Vestal Virgins had to ensure that the fire in her temple did not go out
VICA POTA : an old Roman goddess of Victory, whose festival was on January. She had a temple at the foot of the Velian hill
VOLSCIANS : a people in south Latium who were strong opponents of Rome in the fifth and fourth centuries
